grid package¶

This object returns grid’s scrapping. It has modules/functions to:

  • Search/generate a given grid. Grid

  • Methods to retrieve/store the graph in the database. Database

  • Methods to iterate/walk over generated graphs. Competence

  • Methods to scrapping a new grid. Scrapping

Competence module¶

This module contains some usefull functions to iterate over competencies graphs.

It contains: - A function to create the competecies graphs - A function to iterate over these created graphs and calculate the propagated value

class modules.grid.Competence.BFS[source]¶

Bases: object

An object created to encapsulate all elements and calls that are used in DFS.

New in version 0.0.8.

static generate_graphs(out: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, nodes: networkx.classes.digraph.DiGraph) → Dict[str, networkx.classes.digraph.DiGraph][source]¶

A method used to create a simple graph which, in the end of dfs walk(), will be the sum of 1.

Parameters

  • out – The dataframe that makes the correlation for subject and its competence

  • nodes – The base graph, which contains all the needed nodes.

Returns

A dictionary mapping each competence to a given graph (networkx object)

Return type

Dict[str, DiGraph]

Graph example - Desenvolvimento Web¶

In the image above, the values of out are:

Period

Acronym/Subject

Original/Out value

1

HUMI01

0.0435

1

MATI01

0.0870

1

MATI02

0.0870

2

ECOI04

0.0870

4

ECOI09

0.2174

4

MATI04

0.1304

5

ECOI11

0.1304

5

ECOI14

0.0435

9

ECOI25

0.1739

However, due to the normalization made for each period:

\[\forall \text{ period | } \text{subject}_i = \frac{\text{current_subject_value}_i}{\sum_{n=0}^N\text{current_subject_value}_n}\]

Important

The \(\sum\) of each period is equal to 1.0. E.g: \(\sum\text{period}_1 = HUMI01\cdot0.2 + MATI01\cdot0.4 + MATI02\cdot0.4 \equiv 1.0\)

For the period 1:

\[\sum\left(\text{HUMI01}+\text{MATI01}+\text{MATI02}\right) = 0.2175 \ \therefore \ \text{HUMI01} = \frac{0.0435}{0.2175} = 0.2\]

Doing so, we have:

Period

Acronym/Subject

Sum

New value

1

HUMI01

0.2

1

MATI01

0.2175

0.4

1

MATI02

0.4

2

ECOI04

0.0870

1.0

4

ECOI09

0.3478

0.6251

4

MATI04

0.3749

5

ECOI11

0.1739

0.7499

5

ECOI14

0.250

9

ECOI25

0.1739

1.0

Tip

  1. Propagate the current value (acumulated * subject * edge) to the next node.

  2. Sum all returns of children nodes. Doing so, at the end, the value should be between [0,1].

Note

Why don’t use perceptron approach?

R.: Perceptron classifies as 0 or 1 (activate or not the layer), doing so, we will not have the “percentual reference” in the end.

Todo

According to Giovani, we can have a perceptron passing a value between those.

Caution

This method also assumes that, for each period, the maximum obtained value propagated will be 100%. It means that, for each period, the percentual values are normalized.

static walk(grafos: Dict[str, networkx.classes.digraph.DiGraph], notas: Dict[str, float]) → Dict[str, float][source]¶

Walk over all competences(graphs), propagating the current value over each semester.

Complexity

\(\mathcal{O}(n^4)\)

Parameters

  • grafos – A dictionary mapping competences to graphs equivalent.

  • notas – A dictionary mapping class acronym to a given score.

Returns

A dictionary mapping competency to a calculated and propagated value.

Return type

Dict[str, float]

Example

>>> from modules.grid import Competence
>>> from modules import Score
>>> import json
>>> grafos = Competence.BFS.generate_graphs(out, nodes)
>>> student_grid: str = path.join('..','assets','parsed_scores','2016001942.json')
>>> # obtém o histórico de um único estudante
>>> student_grid: json = Score.read_json(student_grid)
# Does some boring stuffs to handle and map a given class to an value ...
>>>
>>> # ... (usully, the greatest one for a subject)
>>> # notas
>>> # anda sobre o grafo para o(s) aluno(s)
>>> notas_aluno = Competence.BFS.walk(grafos, notas)

Important

  • The accumulated is multiplied by each competence in the current period

  • The accumulated is equivalent to the sum of the previous period

static walk(grafos: Dict[str, networkx.classes.digraph.DiGraph], notas: Dict[str, float]) → Dict[str, float][source]¶

Walk over all competences(graphs), propagating the current value over each semester.

Parameters

  • grafos – A dictionary mapping competences to graphs equivalent.

  • notas – A dictionary mapping class acronym to a given score.

Returns

A dictionary mapping competency to a calculated and propagated value.

Return type

Dict[str, float]

Example

>>> from modules.grid import Competence
>>> from modules import Score
>>> import json
>>> grafos = Competence.BFS.generate_graphs(out, nodes)
>>> student_grid: str = path.join('..','assets','parsed_scores','2016001942.json')
>>> # obtém o histórico de um único estudante
>>> student_grid: json = Score.read_json(student_grid)
# Does some boring stuffs to handle and map a given class to an value ...
>>>
>>> # ... (usully, the greatest one for a subject)
>>> # notas
>>> # anda sobre o grafo para o(s) aluno(s)
>>> notas_aluno = Competence.DFS.walk(grafos, notas)

Important

This function calculates the sum propagated over all “subgraphs” that can exist in a single DiGraph. For example, take a look in the figure (Graph example - Desenvolvimento Web). In this figure, we have 3 independent subgraphs (We are assuming that, HUMI01|MATI01|MATI02 are indepedent graphs since they are not directly connected with each other). For those situations, this method sum the output of all subgraphs.

Note

This function runs the modules.grid.Competence.__dfs_walk() for all competences. Bellow you can check the manual debugging for this method.

Database module¶

This module it’s responsable to store/retrieve the graphs from mongodb.

class modules.grid.Database.Grids(connectionString)[source]¶

Bases: object

This class is responsable to get/put grids into database.

Example

>>> # importing this module
>>> from modules.grid.Database import Grids
>>> grids_module = Grids(mongo_connection_string)
>>> unexistent_courseCode = "coxinha"
>>> # throw this AssertionError
>>> assert unexistent_courseCode in grids_module, "It will throw this error"
close()[source]¶

Close mongo’s connections

get(grid: str) → Tuple[networkx.classes.digraph.DiGraph, networkx.classes.digraph.DiGraph][source]¶

Get object then convert it to graph again

Parameters

grid – Equivalent grid number.

Returns

(pre, co) Pre and corequisites (digraphs)

Return type

Tuple

Raises

Exception – if couldn’t fetch some object with this courseCode.

set(grid: str, GraphPreReq: networkx.classes.digraph.DiGraph, GraphCoReq: networkx.classes.digraph.DiGraph) → None[source]¶

Convert graphs to json, then, to string. After that, store it into database.

Parameters

  • grid – A grid string like. E.g: “0192015”

  • GraphPreReq – A networkx.DiGraph, where the edges are the pre requisite

  • GraphCoReq – A networkx.DiGraph, where the edges are the co requisite

Tip

Check it out the Grid module.

Grid module¶

This module contains the functions which check for existency and, if didn’t found, scrap it from sigaa’s systems.

Todo

Implement loggers and tests for Grid

modules.grid.Grid.get_grid(grid: str, connection: str) → Tuple[networkx.classes.digraph.DiGraph, networkx.classes.digraph.DiGraph][source]¶

Get this grid. If the grid is not in database. Got it and then, store in database

Parameters

  • grid – The grid id. E.g, ‘0192015’

  • connection – The connection string needed to access mongodb

Returns

A tuple containing the pre and co requisite (networkx.DiGraph)

Return type

Tuple[DiGraph, DiGraph]

A class used to generate dot files.

See also

See more on Graphviz

edge(father: str, son: str, style: str, color: str)[source]¶

Create connection

Parameters

  • father – ‘From’ node

  • son – ‘To’ node

  • style – edge style.

  • color – edge color.

Example

>>> a = DotFile()
>>> a.edge('A','B') # create a connection A→B
getDot(filename: str)[source]¶

Gerate dot file.

Parameters

filename – Name to save dot’s file.

Example

>>> a = DotFile()
>>> a.getDot('/home/ppcamp/Desktop/test.dot')
node(nodeName: str, label: str, color: str, fillcolor: str, style: str, shape: str, pos: str) → None[source]¶

Insert string used to create a node.

Parameters

  • nodeName – Name used to make connections.

  • label – Name showed in graph.

  • color – Border color.

  • fillcolor – Fill color.

  • pos – Inch absolute position.

  • shape – Form shape

  • style – Form style, i.e., filled or striped

Example

>>> dotfile = DotFile()
>>> dotfile.insert( 'CEI039','CEI039', 'black', 'white', '4,0!', 'rectangle', 'filled')
modules.grid.Plot.only_grid(nodes, pre, co, filename='grid', outputDir='out') → None[source]¶

Get a student view of grid fluxogram. This plot bot edges, pre and co requisite. It run a system call to graphviz.

Args

  • nodes: A list containing the nodes.

  • pre: A list containing the edges for this graph.

  • co: A list containing the edges for this graph.

Kwargs

  • filename: The name of the file to save (image name). DEFAULT: grid

  • outputDir: The directory to save. DEFAULT: out

Important

The nodes must be ordered by period of the class.

modules.grid.Plot.weighted_graph(nodes: networkx.classes.reportviews.NodeView, edges: List[Tuple[str, str, Dict[str, float]]], filename: str = 'grid', outputDir: str = 'out') → None[source]¶

Get a student view of grid fluxogram/graph. This function make a system call to graphviz.

Args

  • nodes: A list containing the nodes.

  • edges: A list containing the edges for this graph.

Kwargs

  • filename: The name of the file to save (image name). DEFAULT: grid

  • outputDir: The directory to save. DEFAULT: out

Important

The nodes must ne ordered by period of the class.

Tip

Usually, you can get an example graph in modules.grid.Grid.get_grid()

Scrapping module¶

This module is responsable to open the sigaa system and then scrapy if don’t find the course in mongodb database.

Todo

Missing loggers for:

  • scrapping_grid()

modules.grid.Scrapping.scrapping_grid(courseCode: str) → Tuple[networkx.classes.digraph.DiGraph, networkx.classes.digraph.DiGraph][source]¶

Load the credentials under src/certs/credentials.json file, logon into sigaa’s system and then, scrap it, retriving a new graph to a certain grid string

Parameters

courseCode – Course number, e.g, “0192015”

Returns

A tuple with (pre,co) requisite graphs equivalents to this courseCode

Return type

Tuple[DiGraph, DiGraph]

Note

We only add the graph the connection

Caution

This graph ain’t check for equivalency. It means that when using student’s history, you’ll problably need to check for equivalency too.
